titleStmt.title: An overview of optimization technologies applied in combined cooling, heating and power systems

analytic.title: An overview of optimization technologies applied in combined cooling, heating and power systems

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: CCHP Optimization algorithm Multi-objective System design Control strategy Renewable energy

div.p: Combined cooling, heating and power (CCHP) systems have the advantages of higher energy efficiency and lower economic and environmental impacts (3E) than separated systems. Recently, optimization methods have been extensively applied in CCHP system's design and control for further improving 3E performances of CCHP systems. However, a wide range of subsystems selection, nonlinear characteristics of subsystem models and uncertainty in modeling results of CCHP systems cause challenges for successful implementation of optimization studies at both design and control stage. This paper presents a systematic review of all aspects of optimization for CCHP systems from problem formulation and algorithms selection to technical implementation. Genetic algorithm, particle swarm optimization and differential evolution are the most common algorithms used in system optimum design and control. Optimization works in design stage focus on optimization of energy source, prime mover, storage system, energy demand and system configuration. Over 60% of renewable energy integrated CCHP system adopted solar energy. More investigations are needed for small scale prime mover and economic is the development obstacle among 3E objectives. Dynamic characteristics and mal-distribution problem should earn more attention when optimizing storage system in CCHP. For the system control aspects, the baseline control strategy of load-following method as well as optimum control under real-time data and uncertainty condition are discussed. The intermittent feature of renewable energy should be considered at system control stage with uncertainty study. Uncertainty inside of energy demands, subsystems performance and market price should be investigated at the same time during control stage. Overall, this review paper can be used as an optimization reference and guidance for optimum CCHP system design and control.

div.head: CCHP system
div.p: Combined cooling, heating and power (CCHP) system is named directly from energy demand types, it is an efficient method to provide two kinds of thermal energy and electricity simultaneously. An energy flow structure in a specific CCHP system is illustrated in Fig. 1. The top lines represent energy sources, the rectangular boxes represent energy conversion technologies, the circular boxes represent energy demands (electricity demand, cooling demand and heating demand) and bottom lines represent energy storage systems. These four elements form a sustainable energy system and can be enriched by utilizing renewable energy, adopting various conversion technologies and expanding functions. In conventional CCHP systems, prime mover (PM) such as gas turbine (GT) converts primary energy into electricity. The waste heat otherwise discharged is recovered for space heating and cooling demands through absorption cooling (ABC) or absorption heating (ABH). Auxiliary components such as electric chiller (EC), heat pump (EH) or boiler are added to the system to fulfill extra cooling and heating demands when necessary. Overall, a CCHP system can achieve over 80% overall energy efficiency for different primary energy inputs, which is much higher than separated generation systems [1]. CCHP system capacity ranges from below 20 kW to above 10 MW. And it has proliferated in residential applications from commercial applications due to expansion of small-scale power generation units (PGU) such as microturbine (MT), Stirling engine (SE) and fuel cell (FC).

There are three steps for a CCHP system to be implemented successfully: components modeling, system planning and system control [2]. Accurate mathematical modeling provides detailed characteristics of every components and energy flow, and sets the basis for the next two stages. During the planning stage, energy conversion technologies https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rser.2019.109344 Received 3 January 2019; Received in revised form 15 August 2019; Accepted 15 August 2019 and subsystems' capacities are decided. In the last stage, the system control strategies are designed and implemented. No matter in which stages of implementing a CCHP system, decision makers are always seeking for higher energy efficiency, lower economic cost, and lower environmental impact (3E). Therefore, optimization is a topic that cannot be ignored.

div.head: Previous review works
div.p: The first review work on CCHP system was carried out in 2006 by Wu and Wang [1]. In this paper, the essential advantages of CCHP system compared with separated system were introduced first. Then, the authors presented the characteristics of PM and thermal activated cooling subsystem. They then classified different technologies by capacity range, application limitation, energy efficiency and environmental impact. At last, the author summarized typical system configurations and system level development status throughout the world. Al Moussawi [3] outlined a component-based review for CCHP system including PMs, heat recovery units and thermal storage systems. This paper provided detailed technology comparisons and suggested a general selection method of appropriate CCHP system for specific applications. As one of the crucial components in CCHP system, PM determines the downstream subsystem configuration and performance. There is a review work provided a thorough analysis of applicable PMs and selection criteria [4]. Al-Sulaiman et al. [5] also investigated CCHP system with two or more PMs. Angrisani et al. [6] reviewed the development progress of small-scale PM in trigeneration systems. The authors emphasized energy and environmental benefits of small-scale systems and pointed out that the high initial cost is the dominant obstacle for market penetration. Rong and Su [7] traced the advantages of polygeneration systems in terms of zero energy buildings and concluded that optimization of micro-and small-scale system is more complicated than large-scale system due to technical, legal and policy constrains. Other review papers that summarized component model, system However, there is no comprehensive review work focusing on optimization study of CCHP systems.

div.head: Scope and purpose of this paper
div.p: The main scope of this paper is to summarize various optimization techniques and algorithms applied to CCHP systems at different stages. Although the optimization techniques for CCHP system have been welldiscussed in lots of literature, a clear and systematic review work summarizing all aspects of optimization for CCHP systems from problem formulation, algorithms selection to technique implementation does not exist to the author's best knowledge. In some papers, enumerated number of design cases or conducting parametric study is adopted to produce a best result under limited circumstances and is treated as optimization. However, it is limited to insufficient variables and cannot guarantee a global optimum. For a complex system like CCHP, the best design or operation strategy is always related to various variables and conditions. Therefore, the authors focused on papers that stick to mathematical optimization investigation. Another inappropriate usage of 'optimization' is incorrectly grouping optimization at planning stage into the category of control stage. The authors are intent to clarify different aspects of optimization for CCHP systems. In addition, comprehensive investigations of optimization aspects for CCHP system will help identify advantages and limitations of different optimization techniques when designing and controlling CCHP systems. Overall, this review paper can be used for an optimization reference and guidance for optimum CCHP system design and control based on researcher's preference.

div.head: Overview of CCHP system optimization
div.p: The standard process of CCHP system optimization design can be expressed in Fig. 2. Formulating the design, planning or control problem into an optimization problem is the first step. The formulation of CCHP system optimization problem has been maturely developed to a specific format since the concept of cogeneration system came out earlier. Related information including variable energy market price, intermittent renewable energy, and uncertainty in demands should be investigated ahead. In general, CCHP system optimization can be categorized into single objective or multi-objective optimization based on decision-makers' priorities. Nowadays, enrichment in optimization techniques and improvement in computation performance enable decision makers to concern more about multi-objective problem. Problem formulation is followed by mathematical modeling and baseline estimation. In this step, physics-based or correlation-based models are developed. These models serve as optimization constrains. Some other practical constrains such as operation and space limitations also need to be considered. The baseline estimation is calculated based on separated energy supply system design, which is used for performance evaluation of optimal CCHP system and result comparison. Last, optimization techniques are used reciprocally to realize objectives. A large amount of system designs has been proposed since the concept of CCHP system came out, which resulted in intensive research work on optimal design, planning and control of CCHP system. Fig. 3 shows paper published with optimization studies in the area of CCHP based on ScienceDirect online database [11] by searching the keyword 'combined cooling, heating power and optimization'. A total of 232 papers have been identified after screening out those not relevant to the topic, which also include 17 papers related to district energy system (DES). It is obvious that the application of optimization has been continuously increasing since 2015. It results from the expansion of optimization techniques into the energy system management area and the computational power improvement.

Overview of CCHP system optimization can be categorized as shown in Fig. 4. At design stage, system working conditions are determined through thermodynamic level optimization. Parameters like compressor pressure ratio, inlet temperature, pressure, pinch point temperature, heat exchanger's evaporating or condensing temperature, efficiency, and many others are optimization variables. Moreover, capacities and configurations are decided through design optimization. At planning stage, partial load allocations are optimized based on developed system models and predicted input values. Combining the design and planning optimization is the conventional approach for proposed system optimization. At control stage, real-time demands, energy conversion subsystems performance and market price would partially or heavily deviate from predicted values. Therefore, we need to adopt optimization techniques to deal with control problems under uncertainty.

div.head: Optimization formulation
div.p: A general optimization problem can be expressed as following mathematical model: objectives, equality and inequality constrains in Eq. ( 1) where both continuous (x) and discrete integers (y) are involved. CCHP system optimization problem can be assorted based on numbers of objectives, features of variables and characteristics of constrains. The optimization variables are subsystem capacities, partial load information, on-off signals and storage states for energy storage systems. (1)

div.head: Objectives
div.p: As mentioned before, energy efficiency, economic cost, environmental impact and sometime exergy efficiency are considered as optimization objectives. There are various definitions for these objectives, especially for energy part. The choice of energy efficiency objective indicator may vary based on researcher's preference. Primary energy consumption (PEC) [12] and energy utilization factor (EUF) [13] are the most used and evaluated energy indicators, which are expressed in Eq. ( 2) and Eq. ( 3), where F and Q are defined as fuel (or natural gas) consumption and recovered heat for hot water, space heating, thermally activated cooling device, m represents mass flow rate of fuel. The total PEC is calculated by indexes of electricity (PEC e ) and natural gas (PEC NG ). This definition is better for tracing back all PEC, whereas the bought and sold electricity should not be indexed by the same indicator and it is neither convenient nor flexible when it comes to multi-objective optimization and multiple primary energy sources (solar or wind). As for EUF, it shows some degree of energy efficiency by using demanded primary energy and lowest heating value. However, it is not suitable to simply sum up different energy product and not flexible to expand the primary energy sources. (2)

div.p: Therefore, it is necessary to come up with an equation that takes flexibility of PE source, uniformity of energy supply and convenience of optimization into consideration. A modified PEC equation primary energy efficiency (PEE) expressed in Eq. ( 4) is proposed to combine the advantages of above mentioned two functions. Here, PE is similar to the function of PEC NG in Eq. ( 2) but with a broader energy source range, including solar, wind, NG, etc., which correspond to different technologies (i). Ex i is described as exhaust heat that cannot be used any- more and dumped into environment for different energy conversion technologies. The value can be calculated by using system efficiency or detailed thermodynamic model.

For economic objective, primary energy cost, electricity cost from grid, operation and maintenance, equipment cost (C i ) are consider. It can be roughly expressed in Eq. ( 5). Sometime, the economic objective evolves into payback period, net present value, net profit, annual total cost, etc. As for emission objective, it is highly related to PE sources due to different emission rate (ER i ). div.p: Moreover, in order to have a convenient comparison and make a decision among the multiple objectives, energy, exergy, cost, and CO 2 emission objective values are sometimes normalized to the same scale by the value of separated energy supply systems (SESS), in which these four aspects should be calculated simultaneously. Overall, Eq. ( 8) expresses the idea of maximizing four aspects of CCHP optimization in terms of primary energy efficiency increase rate (PEEIR), total cost reduction rate (TCRR), carbon dioxide reduction rate (CDRR) and exergy efficiency increase rate (XEIR). Since higher emission and energy efficient devices generally require a higher investment, objectives of energy utilization factor and total cost rate explicitly conflict, but others may be implicitly conflict. In addition, multi-objective problem usually does not have a unique solution, as compared with a single objective problem, which usually aims at identifying a local maximum or minimum and possibly finding the global optimum. The predominant solution concept in defining solutions for multi-objective optimization problems is Pareto efficient solution set [14]. This set can be projected to the objective function space to form a Pareto optimal front. The multi-objective optimization methods are trying to get solutions that are close to Pareto optimal front [15]. It should be noted that every single objective in CCHP system is a quite simple linear function. Whereas, the optimization complexity comes from constrains.

div.head: Constrains
div.p: The optimization constrains are defined by energy conversion subsystem models and contain the information of mass and energy conservations. As illustrated in Fig. 1, different equipment converts primary energy, electricity or waste heat into heating, cooling and electricity demand. Eq. ( 9) can express constrains of a general CCHP system by energy flow balance. For more general system optimization tasks, time steps are reflected in following constrains formulation.

There are also technical constrains for each energy conversion subsystems, which can be showed in Eq. (4). For each type of energy demand (j), there are always three kinds of energy source supplied: primary energy, waste heat and electricity. α β, η and Cp are described as on-off signal, partial load, subsystem effi- ciency and subsystem capacities separately. In practical operation, there should be ramp limitations for subsystems, especially for slow responding subsystems, which is indicated by β i lim2 ). Overall, both continuous and discrete variables involved in CCHP optimization.

div.p: Constrains construction of total cost and CO 2 emission is much simpler than energy aspect as indicated in Eq. ( 5) and Eq. (6). The prices of primary energy and electricity are time-related values, which can be referred from IEA [11] or utility company policy. The equipment cost, operation and maintenance are always correlation based on technologies, capacities, site location, etc. As for environmental impact, the general treatment is considering the CO 2 generation due to primary energy and electricity. Different energy sources combined with different energy conversion subsystems have specific CO 2 emission rates. Certainly, the value of emission rate is also related to time serial when the effect of ambient conditions on subsystems are considered.

To be more specific, for CCHP system design shown in Fig. 1, energy balance constrains can be expressed as Eq. (11). Actually, primary energy sources and the techniques described by vectors ( α η [ ] i t i t j ) are flexible and can be expanded based on available primary energy sources and technologies, such as solar PV, wind turbine, Kalina cycle, adsorption cycle, etc. Two types of approach are used to describe these subsystems performance η i . First, the subsystem is modeled by a thermodynamic cycle where nonlinearity of system performance is expressed implicitly. Combined with binary on-off variables the optimization problem turns to be mixed integer nonlinear programming (MINLP) problem. CCHP system is simulated for obtaining the optimal design condition, that is to say, component dimension like heat exchanger, capacity of gas turbine, inlet pressure and temperature, etc. There is limited research work that uses this method to conduct a long term operation optimization since the complexity of nonlinear characteristics in the thermodynamic model make the optimization hard to converge. Luo and Fong [16] adopted commercial software like TRNSYS to simulate the whole CCHP system and evolutionary algorithms to conduct optimization process, however, no inlet and outlet information of equipment were provided. Safari et al. [17] model the CHP system in software IPSEpro and GA from MATLAB toolbox to conduct optimization, but no storage system is integrated. That means the system has limited function of load shift and less energy efficient, which also made the problem to be a static problem since the optimization finished at current time slot has no influence on the result of optimization at next time result. Powell et al. [18] researched system by adopting a hybrid CCHP system model, in which gas turbine is a physical model based and other equipment is correlation based. The dynamic problem is decoupled into static sub-problem and sub-problem results are reported back to the dynamic problem so as to quite decreasing computational time from 27 h to 30-40 minus. This procedure also arouses a drawback that the optimum might largely deviate from global optimum.

div.p: The second approach is correlation-based method, which stems from the actual performance under partial load and ambient conditions. The explicit expression of subsystems performance by correlations helps researchers focus on optimization aspects without crossing the modeling platforms but also loss subsystem accuracy and dynamic characteristics. These correlations of subsystems are developed and summarized from experiment data or modeling work. They can be further divided into nonlinear, linear and constant. Within the reviewed papers, the nonlinearity always follows a format expressed like Eq. ( 12), where Temp, P, RH represent for ambient temperature, pressure, relative humility. Despite that linear or piecewise linear correlations are used to approximate the nonlinearity of subsystems for further decrease the computational cost in some research paper, the optimization problem remains to be MINLP because of binary variables α i t in Eq. ( 4). As long as the efficiency function is extremely simplified to a constant value, for instance, the COP of compression chiller is 3 and absorption one is 0.7. In this manner, the complexity of modeling will be greatly decreased, especially for middle and long term based optimization.

Tuning subsystem with only on-off states rather than any partial load possibility is another condition that can to turn the problem into linear optimization programming. Then, the whole optimization problem is formed to be a mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model. This simplified process should be avoid during operation optimization due to over-optimistic subsystem performance, although it is much easier and faster to get an optimum point compared with MINLP. It might be used for short term analysis roughly or comparison with separated energy supply system design and control.

div.head: Time step
div.p: Time range and resolution can highly influence the optimization process of CCHP. In optimization process, the time range can be treated as daily, weekly, monthly or yearly. As for resolution, hourly is recommended for short and middle term and daily is suggested for long term like yearly. Typical four-season weather information is used when daily or weekly time range is chosen. Typical meteorological year (TMY3) data sets are used for yearly analysis. Under some special circumstance, such as no storage systems [19], static optimization occurs. Otherwise, a huge number of variables and parameters make the problem cumbersome due to complexity and multi-time steps of CCHP system. Two methods are proposed by research to deal with this large scale problem. First is by the aforementioned decoupling method [13]. The idea of this method is setting two steps to solve an MINLP problem: solving a problem without binary variables first and then applying the optimization result to multiple time steps to get optimal binary variables. Second is a rolling horizon method similar to the idea of model predictive control (MPC) method [21]. The whole time range optimization procedure is replaced by a fixed short time period optimization and feedback correction of the first time step. But it requires the feedback information of actual system performance and is better for realtime control. In a word, no matter which method is used, there is always a tradeoff between accuracy and computational efficiency.

div.head: Optimization algorithms
div.p: Analytical approach and numerical approach are two types of approaches to solving optimization problems. Analytical approach requires stricter mathematical proofs and derivatives, which are not suitable for practical problems such as CCHP optimization. Compared with analytical method, numerical method provides approximate optimal solution with the help of feedback information about the objectives and variables through iterations. It can be a black box problem without obvious expressions [15]. Therefore, numerical method is more appropriative for CCHP optimization. And most of the numerical methods can be found in Ref. [22].

div.head: Single objective optimization
div.p: As mentioned before, involving binary variables and nonlinear or linear constrains is the feature of CCHP system optimization problem, which yield an MINLP or MILP problem. There are various solvers that can be used to solve these types of problems. MINLP solvers take advantages of mature NLP and MILP solvers. For MILP solvers, the most well used commercial solvers are CPLEX from IBM [39] and Gurobi from Gurobi Optimization [40]. Some open source solver such as Cbc from COIN-OR initiative [41] is well recognized also. Branch and bound (BB) and branch and cut (BC) are the algorithms behind these three MILP solvers. However, BB is not suitable for large scale problems since the number of iterations grows exponentially with the number of variables. BC algorithm is based on BB algorithm and reformulates the set space by using a preprocessing step and cutting planes. As for NLP solver, CONOPT [42], SNOPT [43] and open source IPOPT [44] are well-known options, in which CONOPT utilizes generalized reduced gradient method, SNOPT uses a sequential quadratic programming method and IPOPT implements interior point method. More details about solvers, suitable models, algorithms, and realization platform can be checked in Table 1. It should be noted that the table only list platforms that used for corresponding CCHP optimization problem. Actually, most of the solvers have standalone version and the most welldistributed solver interfaces are GAMS, AMPL, AIMMS, and remote server NEOS. Therefore, previously mentioned solvers can be implemented on multiple platforms based on preference and availability of researchers.

Evolutionary algorithms (EA) like particle swarm optimization algorithm (PSO) and genetic algorithm (GA) are used to optimize the system design and control. Detailed information of evolutionary algorithms can be checked in the following section. CCHP system model can be thermodynamic based or correlation based. Under most of the circumstances, there is no storage system in CCHP when optimizing the control strategies [45], or there are pre-assigned candidate control strategies such follow electricity method when optimizing system design (capacity and equipment number) [46]. The optimization tried to optimization the capacities of subsystems for getting the best cost under specific candidates.

There are also a few researchers combine EA and BB/BC algorithms to figure out the design and control at the same time. Li et al. [30] use GA to optimize the out layer capacity problem and use Gurobi optimizer to solve the inner layer control problem. In addition, forecast errors of demand and PV power are considered in the modeling work to conduct robust optimization.

div.head: Multi-objective optimization
div.p: For the purpose of obtaining a trade-off solution for the multiple and conflicting objectives of CCHP optimization, researchers started with classical multi-objective methods. The classical multi-objective optimization methods include weight method and ε-constrain method. They are advantageous for simplifying the objective function. The weight method is widely used due to the simple procedure of dealing with multi-objective. However, it is not easy to decide the weight of each objective. It is more likely that different objectives will take different orders of magnitude. Therefore, it is much more appropriate to scale these objectives so that each of them has a similar order of magnitude. Here, several priori methods such as technique for order preference by similarity to ideal solution (TOPSIS) [66], linear programming technique for multidimensional analysis of preferences (LINMAP) [67] and analytic hierarchy process (AHP) [68] are adopted to select the weight factor. However, insufficient number of Pareto solutions would be produced sometime with weight method, which makes it difficult to exactly obtain the frontier of the Pareto profile [69]. Moreover, it is impossible to use weight method under the conditions where Pareto front has a concave portion. ε-constrain method comes out for solving these problems. Even though the computational complexity is relatively higher than the weight method, it produces better Pareto results than weight method. However, the classical algorithms require a priori preference information and they are ineffective for nonconvex objective space overall. Although these algorithms converge fast, they only obtain local optimum, which means the global optimum depends on the initial guess. In addition, the feasible region should be continuous for efficient searching. Furthermore, it is hard to implement them on a parallel machine since they use point by point approach, where only one solution gets updated in one iteration.

In order to deal with the limitations of classical methods, evolutionbased algorithms are adopted for CCHP system optimization. The most common evolution-based algorithms used in CCHP system are GA, nondominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA), PSO and differential evolution algorithm (DEA) as listed in Table 2. These methods are also called nature-inspired metaheuristics methods since they make no assumptions about the optimization problem and can search in very large spaces for candidate solutions. Nature-inspired methods use stochastic ideas and random numbers in their calculations to search for the optimum point. They tend to converge to a global optimum point for the evolution, though there is no guarantee for the convergence or global optimality of the final solution [14]. GA is a kind of stochastic optimization algorithm that emulates the mechanics of natural evolution. It has no clear stop criterion in every generation and is difficult to operate on a dynamic data set. However, it is still attractive due to its reduced tendency of converging to local space. NSGA is different from GA for generating offspring and sorting pattern, the offspring population and parent population of NSGA are combined to form a population of size 2n, and a non-dominated sorting method is used to classify the entire population. And parents are selected based on fitness and crowd distance. There is no extra diversity control needed and elitism prevent an already found Pareto front being deleted by using NSGA method. PSO is a population-based stochastic optimization technique developed by Eberhart and Kennedy in 1995 [70], which is inspired by flocking behavior of animals in their movement. Unlike GA, PSO has no evolution operator. And particles update themselves with the internal velocity. Therefore, it is easy to implement and there are few parameters to adjust. As for DEA, it is similar to GA, but the new generation is [23], YALMIP [24], AIMMS [25], AMPL [26] Gurobi MILP, MIQP Barrier and Simplex EAGERS [20], AMPL [27,28], Gurobi [29], YALMIP [ produced by current designs and certain random operations. The new design will be used to replace the pre-selected parent design if the performance is better. Compared with GA, DEA is easier to implement on the computer since it doesn't require binary number coding and encoding. The advantages and disadvantages of these algorithms were reviewed by Cui et al. [15] and Deb et al. [22], and are summarized in Table 3. Optimization algorithm comparison is important when taking computational efficiency into consideration. A fast calculating algorithm is essential for online optimum control. However, there is not much work specified in algorithm comparison in CCHP system optimization. Li et al. [71] proposed a quantum GA (QGA) algorithm for optimizing CCHP-GSHP coupling system. The results showed that QGA method is more stable and efficient than simple GA method. Zhu et al. [72] compared NSGA and stochastic selection algorithm and found the latter is much easier and faster to implement. There is always a tradeoff between different algorithms. Therefore, other algorithms, such as weight method, ε-constrain method, DEA and PSO should be considered for a comprehensive comparison.

div.head: Optimization implementation
div.p: The overall purposes of the CCHP system optimization are improving energy efficiency, reducing total cost and GHG emissions. Considering that the objectives of economic cost, energy saving, and CO 2 emission usually conflict with each other, optimization study that aims at finding trade-offs among these objectives is one of the primary goals for researchers worldwide. Among the optimization scopes of CCHP system shown in Fig. 4, design optimization and control optimization are the two main streams. In the design stage, optimization can be implemented for a single subsystem, such as PM, storage system, or whole system configuration or optimal operation conditions. As for control stage optimization, different optimization-based control strategies from simple load following method to practical model predictive control are introduced.

div.head: Optimization at design stage
div.p: Parameters such as capacities are one of the major concerns for CCHP design optimization. Appropriate capacity sizing will guarantee energy efficiency under partial load conditions, as well as whole year performance. Under the circumstance of large energy demands [73], it is reasonable to design CCHP system with multiple energy conversion subsystems and the subsystems only operate with on or off state, which means any subsystem is at full load or turned off. The variables that need to be decided are the number of subsystems and when to switch them on. CCHP System operation planning is investigated at design stage since only predicted data is considered and no uncertainty information is used. Operation planning is studied after deciding the capacity of the subsystems. Energy sources, energy conversion NSGA/NSGA-II Niching is performed; deciding tournaments is deterministic; avoid chaotic perturbations of the population composition continuously by updated fitness sharing Niching function is too complex, and scales poorly as number of objectives increases subsystems, storage subsystems and energy demands are four elements in a typical CCHP system. Every element requires detailed design optimization for achieving better 3E performance. Therefore, following subchapters summarize CCHP system design optimization based on CCHP system energy flow structure.

div.head: Energy source
div.p: Waste heat is a common alternative heat source for thermally activated energy conversion technologies, while the primary energy comes from fossil fuels. Hou et al. [66] developed a CCHP system for shipboard, in which the working fluid of every subsystem is either supercritical or transcritical CO 2 . Environment impact was decreased by adopting natural working fluid. The objective is to minimize cost and size by TOPSIS. Apart from conventional energy sources, renewable energy has been widely applied in CCHP systems and expanded from solar to biomass, geothermal and wind energy. Different energy sources to power CCHP systems are summarized in Fig. 5.

5.1.1.1. Solar energy. Solar energy is the most common renewable energy source in CCHP systems. Solar PV and thermal collectors are two primary methods that utilizing solar energy, in which solar thermal part can be integrated into CCHP system at various locations due to flexible temperature ranges according to the property of working fluids.

The solar thermal collector model can be represented by constant efficiency [74], or temperature-based ones, e.g. linear [75], polynomial [76] or detailed one [77]. And it is similar for solar PV modeling (constant [78], linear [79], polynomial [62], detailed [80]). The detailed and polynomial efficiency approach is frequently used when conducting thermodynamics-based cycle optimization.

Solar thermal in CCHP systems is a common heat source for ORC, ABC or direct heating in conventional utilization. Rashidi and Khorshidi [81] adopted both solar thermal and PV in CCHP systems, as well as fresh water system. The system consists of a reverse osmosis desalination unit, water heater, ORC, photovoltaic solar collectors, and a single effect ABC. DEA and fuzzy clustering were used to find the minimum cost and maximum exergy efficiency through thermodynamic models. The model of solar PV system is simplified as constant efficiency. There is no explicit information about the applicable ranges of the cost correlations. Shirazi et al. [82] proposed three configurations of solarpowered absorption chiller systems for cooling and heating. Evacuated flat plate collectors powered double-effect ABC has the best trade-off between the energetic, economic and environmental performance as compared with evacuated tube collector powered single effect ABC and parabolic trough collectors powered triple effect ABC. Jabari et al. [35,36] designed a solar dish Stirling CCHP system and applied MINLP to the thermodynamics-based optimization to minimize the cost. Ebrahimi and Keshavarz [77] designed the orientation and size of a solar thermal collector for a hybrid CCHP system with consideration of five different climates. Morini et al. [74] used a ratio and fraction based model to simulate a solar-powered CCHP system for residential application. The authors found primary energy consumption could be zero if PV efficiency could reach 20%. The proposed system would be competitive when the efficiency of CHP systems and the COP of heat pumps reach a threshold value, which is hard to maintain in the dynamic condition.

Wang et al. [62] showed that solar thermal integrated CCHP system is more energy efficient but less exergy efficiency than solar PV integrated system. However, due to the intermittent and daytime-occuronly characteristics, CCHP systems with solar energy become more sensitive to weather and cost fluctuation according to the market price. Thus, an accurate energy source and demand prediction and reliable control strategies are needed for efficient and effective solar integrated CCHP systems.

5.1.1.2. Geothermal energy. The intuitive configuration that utilizing geothermal energy is heat pump [83], which shares the function of waste heat from PM. Similar to solar thermal energy, geothermal energy can be used to generate electricity directly or sometimes combined with solar energy. Boyaghchi and Chavoshi [84,85] proposed a geothermally preheated two-stage ORC structured CCHP system. The cooling demand is satisfied by combining an ejector at higher pressure ORC stage. Two decision-making methods, LINMAP and TOPSIS, were used to evaluate the system performance in terms of environment, economic impact and exergy efficiency. Four pairs of working fluid were chosen to assess the monthly performance. R1234ze, R423A, and R134a are optimal fluids in terms of environmental, economic and exergy efficiency aspect, respectively. Li et al. [86] provided an optimum thermodynamic design of geothermally driven CCHP-ORC system. The system would achieve higher efficiency with a lower proportion of dry fluid and a higher proportion of wet working fluid. The geothermal water powered thermal efficiency is relatively low for temperatures around 100 °C.

Theoretically, Kalina cycle is preferred over ORC when geothermal is the only thermal source. ORC is used more often when solar thermal energy attends or zeotropic fluid is used to decrease the irreversible loss. Zare [87] compared geothermally powered Kalina cycle with geothermally powered ORC. The results show the Kalina cycle integrated system has a better second law efficiency of 50.4%. However, the optimization work was conducted through a parametric study, which is insufficient for finding the global optimum. The low utilization characteristic of geothermally powered subsystem in CCHP system results from lower applicable temperature ranges. Even though considerable studies have focused on heat recovery of geothermal water, the pressure recovery has not been explored sufficiently in the optimization work of geothermally powered CCHP system. 5.1.1.3. Biomass and biogas. Biomass or biogas, which can be used as an alternative to fossil fuels, has similar environmental attractions for researchers as solar energy. In terms of CCHP system architecture, the biomass integrated CCHP system is like a conventional one except that the fossil fuel is replaced by gasification subsystem. The increment of components and coupling within subsystems make modeling of CCHP system more complicated and more intensive in computing time.

Exergoeconomic analysis is the mainstream for a biomass-based system. Wang and Yang [88] demonstrated that the biomass subsystem can achieve higher energy and exergy efficiencies in CCHP systems than solar-based subsystem. Wang and Mao [89] showed that the biomass price greatly influences the product unit cost and the exergy cost of cooling water is the most sensitive among all demands. Wang et al. [90] Fig. 5. Utilization of renewable energy in CCHP system optimization.

claimed that most exergy destruction occurs at gasifier subsystem but didn't show environmental and economic benefits over conventional CCHP systems. The comparison work between traditional energy sources and biomass or biogas can be found in Refs. [91,92]. Specifically, Wu et al. [31] compared solar, fossil fuels and biomass-powered ORC-CCHP system through MILP. The results show that the biomass-ORC system has the best environmental performance whereas the solar-ORC system has the best economic benefit. Li et al. [93] proposed biomass-powered ICE-CCHP system and applied TOPSIS to choose the best capacity under load-following control strategy. Overall, there is still a lack in optimization of thermodynamic cycle, design or operation for biomass-powered CCHP systems.

5.1.1.4. Wind energy. Wind energy gained interests among experts of CCHP systems due to its large capacities, clean production process and compatibility with solar-or natural gas-powered systems. However, there is no standalone wind turbine powered system in the scope of CCHP operation. Lorestani and Ardehali [51] optimized solar and wind energy assisted CCHP system by using evolutionary PSO algorithm and validated by DE, PSO, GA and harmony search algorithm (HAS). The best combination is PV/T, WT, EES, TES, ABC, EH under FTL. Li et al. [23] proposed an optimal dispatch strategy for an integrated energy system with wind power, and MILP was formulated to optimize the operation cost.

As a result of various previous efforts, the CCHP system has become more reliable and more flexible in its energy source. However, it also raised difficulties in achieving efficient control under various ambient, load and market conditions. More study should focus on improving the accuracy of control based on energy source characteristics. Under the special application circumstance, the compressed air storage system can be integrated into the WT-CCHP system. However, there is no such investigation.

div.head: Optimal prime mover
div.p: Prime mover is chosen from various technologies like internal combustion engine (ICE), steam turbine (ST), gas turbine (GT), MT, SE, ORC, FC, and photovoltaic (PV) collector based on different energy resources and energy demand structures. Summary of these PMs' characteristics can be found in the work of Al-Sulaiman [5]. Applicable conditions of PMs are differentiated by the power efficiency, typical capacity, power to heat ratio, overall efficiency, capital cost, O&M cost, and CO 2 emission rate. Taking advantages of renewable energy and scaling down subsystem capacity to residential buildings are current trends for microgrid CCHP systems. For small size CCHP systems, FC, MT and SE are the main PMs based on capacity ranges.

div.head: Fuel cell.
div.p: Operating quietly, having few moving parts and requiring less maintenance make FC as a candidate for residential CCHP. Solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) and proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) are the most common FC that are used in CCHP system.

A molten carbonate FC-based CCHP system was compared with traditional ICE, GT and SE driven CCHP system by Hossein Abbasi [47]. The results show that FC based system is less competitive than the other three types of PM due to the relatively high price of FCs in the residential market. Lototskyy et al. [94] proposed a solar thermal powered reversible SOFC. Metal hydride beds were used to improve system performance. The author optimized the operation parameter such as the mass ratio of two metal hydride beds to be 1.15 to get maximum efficiency. Furthermore, H 2 utilization factor, masses of metal hydrides beds were optimized to maximize the COP and efficiency at the same time with the help of NSGA-II. Hou et al. [95] compared the direct combustion based CCHP with solar methanol SOFC-CCHP system. The optimization work was performed through the parametric study on the thermodynamic cycle. The maximum power and thermal efficiencies were 59.7% and 81.6%, respectively. Chen et al. [53,96,97] proposed a 5 kW PEMFC-CCHP system for residential application, which showed predominance in traditional CCHP system. The system was modeled based on the thermodynamic cycle. The FC inlet condition including pressure, RH and temperature were optimized to get optimal 4E benefits. In most of these papers, economic and CO 2 emissions have not been compared with other PMs.

Degradation of FC performance was introduced into the microgrid system's robust optimization [30], and the optimal capacity of every component was computed via GA under uncertainty of PV output as well as the load demand. Jing [98] proposed MINLP model to optimize the design and dispatch of SOFC-CCHP system. ε-constrain method is effective in solving the MINLP model and verified by LINMAP and TOPSIS approaches. The capital cost was about 19-30% of the life cycle cost. Even though the CO 2 emission reduction can reach up to 61%, the optimal levelized cost of energy was around 0.17$/kWh, which was higher than residential electricity price. Facci et al. [99] compared four designs of SOFC-CCHP system. The designs were a combination of two cooling technologies and two types of SOFC. Dynamic programming was used for sorting the optimal operation signal of every component. The capital cost of SOFC significantly impacted the optimal design. A capital cost of 10k€/kW is a critical point that makes a SOFC-based CCHP system to be feasible from economic aspect.

In general, the capital cost is the key issue that hampers the application of FC-based small scale CCHP system. Compared with other mature PMs, the electricity to heat ratio of FC is relatively high, so it is sometimes insufficient to provide thermal cooling energy for ABC. However, EC integrated cooling system can be designed in CCHP system, so there is a need for comparison of FC-based CCHP systems in which cooling is provided by ABC, EC or both.

div.head: Microturbine.
div.p: Researchers have been integrating microturbine (MT) in CCHP since 2000. Early stage researches were focused on CCHP system's thermodynamic analysis and simple operation. However, there is not much work specified on MT-based CCHP system optimization. Huang et al. [100] used GA to find the Pareto front of MT-based CCHP system. However, rated energy demand and a single changeable load in thermal or power side were used for constant load information, which could not reflect the system dynamic characteristics. Sugiartha et al. [101] started to adopt 3E analysis in MT-based CCHP system but no optimization analysis was provided until now. Ebrahimi and Ahookhosh [102] proposed an index integrating energy-exergy to optimize MT, ORC and steam ejector refrigeration-based CCHP system, in which the weight factor is evenly distributed. The optimum pinch point temperatures were 36 °C and 28 °C for summer and winter, respectively. Zhang et al. [54] maximized the energy saving rate and exergy efficiency at the same time with the help of a fitness function. The compressor ratio, ambient temperature, isentropic efficiency and cooling to electric ratio were the decision variables. However, the efficiency would always choose the maximum value to get a higher objective value without any limitation on cost constrain. Therefore, the energy efficiency of subsystems cannot be simply treated as a variable unless economic constrains are included. Wu et al. [103] developed a data-driven predictive controller for the MGT-CCHP system to improve its operating performance. The subspace identification served as the predictor was directly from the input-output data so that modeling process for conventional model predictive control can be eliminated. Das et al. [104] compared MT and PV combined CCHP system with ICE and PV combined CCHP system. The efficiency and total cost were weighted by TOPSIS decision. The cost and efficiency of MT-based system were 0.28$/kWh and 43%, respectively, which fell behind the ICE-based system. 5.1.2.3. Stirling engine. Stirling engine has not been explored much in recent research works. Limited investigations used SE as supplementary PM in CCHP system to further improve energy efficiency of whole system [105,106]. Su et al. [107] compared a solar-biomass-ICE driven CCHP system with a solar-SE assisted, biomass-ICE driven CCHP system in sewage treatment application. The engine capacity was optimized, and the performance of SE integrated system was not as good as hybrid system in terms of annual efficiency. Other research work adopted SE as the main PM were all about system designs, sizing [108] and feasibility analysis [109]. Kaldehi et al. [110] designed a solar SE-driven trigeneration system and mainly focused on SE modeling and verification in different climate regions. However, when the authors tried to analyze the system performance, the thermal load was calculated based on ASHRAE handbook 2007 [111], which is a fixed value and not reflecting the actual demand. Thus, it would not well suit for following electricity/thermal (FTL/FEL) load control strategies. Moghadam et al. [112] used 3E criteria to optimize SE size under FTL/FEL. However, auxiliary device or power was needed under these load following strategies, so there is still some space for improving energy efficiency. Karami and Sayyaadi [113] applied the fuzzy-AHP decision-making method to choose which optimization objective was the best for different cities. However, the fuzzy-AHP method is subjective and depends on researchers' experience, so more objective methods should be considered. Harrod et al. [108] provided a sizing method for SE in CCHP through a parametric study. However, the optimization was a single objective, which is not sufficient for SE design and selection.

Overall, in the PM selection studies mentioned above, SE is sometimes considered less competitive than other PMs when considering the capital cost. While SE shows its development potential in CCHP system, there is a need for more investigation of SE-based CCHP than other small-scale PMs, especially related to the economic analysis. There should be more standalone SE-driven CCHP system optimization work that can promote the application of residential scale CCHP system.

div.head: Prime mover selection.
div.p: The selection of PM in CCHP system varies based on the energy source and 3E criteria, which can be summarized in Table 4. Wang et al. [68] first used multi-criteria (3E + society) to evaluate different PMs based trigeneration systems and found that the gas turbine plus LiBr based-ABC was the best and SOFC-based one was the worst. Wang et al. [114] further integrated entropy information method to weaken the subjective AHP method. The results show that the SE-based system is the ideal one. Ebrahimi and Keshavarz [115] expanded this method to different climate regions. The author concluded that the ranks of PMs from best to worst are ICE, SE, separated system and MT. Climate difference had little influence on selection. However, there were only limited hierarchy criteria in the second layer, which would limit the application of this method. Khorasaninejad et al. [116] combined several other fuzzy approaches to the second layers criteria for selection of PMs in ORC based CCHP system. This work found PV panel to be the best PM and GT the worst when every primary criterion (3E + society) was segmented into 16 to 5 sub-criteria. Roman and Alvey [117] provided the hybrid load following operation based selection method among ICE, MT and phosphoric acid FC. However, the selection was only one layer, so it could only provide the selection in each sub-criterion. Hossein Abbasi et al. [47] used two layers to select the optimum PM and determined the capacity of the PM. In the first layer, multi-criteria decision-making techniques (Fuzzy, TOPSIS, and LINMAP) were used to select the best CCHP configurations among the Pareto optimal sets. In the second layer, a new class of AHP was employed to prioritize the optimal solutions based on each PM selected from the previous layer in any climate zones.

However, the selection of PMs was based on some fixed configurations, which means all components in the CCHP system remained unchanged except PMs. Also, there were not many considerations for operation strategies for different PMs. The reality is that different PMs have their own optimal subsystem configuration and operation strategies, there hasn't been any work based on this premise. In addition, some PMs can be driven by renewable energy. Unfortunately, these studies have little concern about the influence of renewable energy on 3E.

div.head: Optimal storage system
div.p: Storage system is effective when mitigating fluctuation in energy demands and peak shaving characteristics of CCHP systems. Wang and Ma [118] stated that the optimization related to storage systems was a dynamic optimization where a trajectory of design should be determined rather than a single point optimization in a system without storage system, which means the optimization with storage requires significantly increased computation resources.

Zhang et al. [33] considered heating and cooling storage systems and built an MINLP model in GAMS to deal with the dynamic optimization problem. The author targeted at optimal cost and CO 2 emission and solved optimal size and operation strategy through Lindo optimizer. Zheng et al. [119] proposed a novel thermal storage strategy for CCHP system. This strategy determined the operational state of the power generation unit based on the energy demand and the state of the storage system. This method was a complex variant of following demand method by counting the energy of storage into the PM. The simulation results show that charging or discharging as much as possible stored thermal energy would improve system performance up to 20% as compared with the system without thermal storage. Hajabdollahi [120] compared four different storage system configurations when optimizing the capacity and operation strategies of CCHP system. The optimal case shows that total annual profit would increase most for adopting both cooling and heating storage devices. Gu et al. [121] investigated the storage system function in the system optimization with load uncertainty and found the storage system acted better under larger uncertainty of thermal demand.

In addition to traditional sensible thermal storage system [122], some new storage technologies such as phase change material and compressed air have been applied to the CCHP. Compressed air storage system [123] is a little different from regular system configuration. Yao et al. [55] designed a CCHP system based on compressed air storage, and optimized exergy and cost at the same time. The results show that the exergoeconomic performance highly depends on compressor, turbine and heat exchanger operation conditions. Yang et al. [124] combined solar and compressed air storage system to CCHP and improved energy efficiency by 1%. Jabari et al. [35] used MINLP to optimize energy and exergy efficiency of adiabatically compressed air energy storage based CCHP system and resulted in 21.8% and 22.4% lower operational costs under cooling and heating modes, respectively. Latent heat storage is another choice. Ruan et al. [125] adopted an ice storage system into building a CCHP system and found that the system had similar energy efficiency but lower operation cost by using a simple linear programming optimization model. Other technologies such as chemical heat storage systems had much higher energy density and seldom suffered from heat loss problem than sensible storage, but are still under theoretical and laboratory test stage [126]. Li et al. [30] optimized the size of hydrogen storage tank of CCHP system with consideration of performance degradation of FC and battery.

Storage system has the benefit of avoiding the discontinuous operation, increasing the number of operating hours and reducing the investment cost. However, most of the papers have not considered the detailed information of storage systems such as dynamic characteristics of storage system and mal-distribution problem under different conditions.

div.head: Energy demand
div.p: In addition to heating, cooling and power demands, other demands like fresh water can be integrated. Therefore, desalination can be an additional function to be integrated into CCHP system. The system efficiency can be further improved, as well as systems' self-sustainability, especially for shipboard applications.

Shu et al. [127] developed a fresh water production integrated CCHP system based on shipboard ICE. Calise et al. [128] proposed a solar and geothermal hybrid system to produce electrical, thermal, cooling energy and fresh water. The results show that global exergy efficiency varies between 40% and 50% during the thermal recovery mode operation and between 16% and 20% during the cooling mode operation. Mohammadi and Mehrpooya [129] designed a desalination integrated CCHP system, which can provide 46.8 kW power, 451 kW heating, 52 kW cooling and 0.79 kg/s potable water. However, optimal operational parameters were decided based on sensitivity analysis only. Sadeghi et al. [130] designed a novel multi-generation system for producing power, cooling, and fresh water by adopting ejector and humidification/dehumidification desalination technology. The optimal exergy efficiency can reach 17%. Najafi et al. [131] presented thermodynamic, economic and environmental modeling of an SOFC-GT hybrid system integrated with a multi-stage flash desalination unit. The optimal design led to an exergy efficiency of 46.7% and 9 years payback period.

However, most of the research work optimized the system on a thermodynamic level and the practical water demand load could not be reflected. Luo et al. [32] provided an hourly-based water requirement for a 50-houses building group and bi-level MILP optimization methodology was applied. But no related reference for water demand was indicated. In the optimization work, capacities were optimized based on three single objectives in upper level, and operation was optimized based on fuel cost in lower level. However, the capacities were limited to three integer numbers. The single objective optimization model was insufficient to find the optimum design. There lacks in study investigating the water demand in CCHP system optimization by applying multi-objective optimization method. Adopting membrane technologies might be another candidate of desalination subsystem since reverse osmosis process is equally successful as thermal process for commercial production of fresh water [132].

div.head: Configuration optimization
div.p: Configuration optimization during design stage should take aforementioned PMs (or energy conversion part), storage system and energy sources into considerations. Alvarado et al. [133] constructed a technology selection and operation model, which connected a database for a portfolio of available energy technologies. The database categorized different energy conversion technologies by capacity, efficiency and cost. The target is to provide best technology combinations and operation strategies by minimizing cost, GHG emission or both. Although the database is powerful, CHP is presented as a whole system and ORC is the only choice of heat recovery, which excludes some combination possibility such as solar, MT, SE and Kalina cycle. Cao et al. [134] developed a configuration optimization framework by MINLP under single objective (minimizing life-cycle cost), bi-objective (minimizing capital cost and annual fuel energy consumption) and robust optimization (minimizing life-cycle cost considering uncertainties in load profiles). The system conversion part is much more enriched than previous works. However, the storage system was not considered in the optimization work and objectives can be expanded by LINMAP, Fuzzy or TOPSIS methods. Wang et al. [27] considered not only waste heat quantity but also the quality when cascaded different heat recovery technologies in the DES system. Linearization was used to simplify the optimization problem. The model was validated through four different operation modes and the optimized system can improve cost savings by 5% as compared with systems that do not consider waste heat quality. However, waste heat recovery systems were the only part of the configuration optimization work. Other research works that aim at configuration optimization are all enumerated limited number of system combination [135], capacity [136] or working fluid choices [85], which can hardly be called as a configuration optimization. Overall, a more expandable CCHP system would contribute more benefits for energy, environment, and economics. That also means the database should be more powerful and the system would be more complex by increased degrees of freedom. Tian et al. [137] proposed a weak decoupling method for description of energy conversion within CCHP system, which was similar to matrix expression in energy hub. This method was used for subsystem capacity and operation optimization in different load following methods. Based on the decoupling concept, configuration optimization may be relieved.

div.head: Optimal control strategy
div.p: The system optimization during control stage has a great impact on system performance. In control stage, real-time demands and uncertainties from all the four elements of a CCHP system shown in Fig. 1 should be considered. Therefore, control optimization under real-time demand and uncertainty is the main part of this review work. Basic control strategies like load following method (FEL and FTL) would serve as an introduction to CCHP control.

div.head: Load following control
div.p: Load following method is illustrated in Fig. 6. The performance of PM is shown by the solid line, which represents the relationship Fig. 6. Load following method.

between generated electricity and recoverable heat from the exhaust of PM [12]. Any point A or B represents the energy demand at any time. The cooling load is also transferred to heating load through thermally activated technologies such as ABC. Take point A as an example, regulating PM to point A′ means that the system operates under FTL, while point A″ means FEL. It is the same for point B. Overall, the load following method is a matchiness strategy of energy demand and supply. It is observed that energy would be wasted no matter which load following method is used. Thus, some variants from basic load following method like hybrid method [138][139][140] and following minimum distance method [141] are used to reduce energy wasted. Afzali and Mahalec [142] developed a novel performance curve for determining the optimal control strategy for CCHP system based on load following method. Energy price, fuel consumption and CO 2 emission rates were all considered in the novel curve. The case study shows that this methodology leads to the best operation result when compared to other load following strategies based on 3E objectives. However, the load following method and its variants are not optimal control strategies. They can be only used for capacity optimization from the design point of view. In addition, subsystems are oversimplified sometimes, and storage is never investigated in this method. Therefore, it is mainly suitable for simple system and static optimization model.

div.head: Optimum control under real-time condition
div.p: From the optimization viewpoint, the control strategy should not be predefined by the partial load information of PM before searching for the optimum control point, which means stricter constrains are set and optimal point may not be a global optimum. Jayasekara et al. [143] proposed a two-stage optimization algorithm that can search for optimal subsystem capacities and optimize control strategy. Besides, this work projected the objective function to a three-dimensional space to track the system smoothly along the optimum control trajectory. Zhao et al. [144] adopted niche PSO algorithm to obtain a Pareto optimal solution set and implemented it for a hospital case study. The optimal scheme of energy management was provided via TOPSIS method. The results reveal that TOPSIS method can stabilize fluctuation of thermal and electric load. However, these methods are all based on predicted or default energy demand, supply and cost incentives. Therefore, they cannot identify real-time optimal management under practical conditions. Real-time data, like demand and electricity price, have been evaluated in some control optimization studies until recently. Yun et al. [145] considered the transient response of a building combined with a hierarchical CHP optimal control algorithm to obtain a real-time integrated system that uses the most recent weather and electric load information. Sanjari et al. [146] proposed hyper-spherical search (HSS) algorithm to system scheduling problem. This optimization work was evaluated under real load data. The comparison of HSS, colonial competitive algorithm and harmony search algorithm (HSA) shows the benefits of HSS algorithm in optimizing the control of the home energy system. Demand response program was used to further decrease the control cost. Related work can be found in Ref. [147]. MPC is an effective method to tackle the optimization problem with real-time data. Rossi et al. [148] used simplified management control, MPC and multicommodity matcher (MCM) to manage smart distributed system. MCM showed very good global economic performance, but it did not consider energy stored and failed in optimizing the storage vessel. Simple management control and MPC made good use of the thermal storage tank and MPC performed a significant increase in profits over the test. However, MPC method is difficult in tuning up. Other studies in Refs. [149][150][151][152] used MPC iteratively to produce a control sequence for the residential microgrid. All of the work can lead to annual control cost saving. Besides MPC, Hu and Cho [153] proposed a stochastic multiobjective optimization model to optimize the CCHP control strategy for different climate conditions. Probability constrains were added into the model. The results show that a higher reliability level of probability constrain increases the control cost.

div.head: Optimum control under uncertainty
div.p: System operated under real-time data should take discrepancy between practical and predicted demands into consideration. More specifically, uncertainty from energy demand prediction, energy market price and activity schedule should be considered. Stochastic solutions are usually preferred over deterministic solutions since the former provides reliable control strategy in real-world applications [26].

Gu et al. [121] showed that the GT and ABC could be optimized deterministically, while the auxiliary equipment such as the electric chiller and gas boiler should be optimized under the uncertainty of loads. Quoilin et al. [154] modeled the stochastic load behavior and took HSA as the optimization method. The results show that control cost can be decreased by a generated look-up table. Based on the mentioned control methods, Sanjari et al. [155] studied the demand forecast error and claimed that economic dispatch of different energy resources could be achieved by adjusting artificial neural network training input. Lefort et al. [156] used hierarchical MPC strategy to solve the problem of differences between the optimized behavior and the real one. Luo and Fong [16] developed a multi-supply-multi-demand control strategy for year-round control of the SOFC-GT-CCHP system under varying climatic and loading conditions. Rolling optimization and feedback correction were used to determine units' control and rectify the prediction errors, respectively. Luo et al. [24] proposed a two-stage control approach including the economic dispatching stage and the real-time adjusting stage, to solve the uncertainty problems in optimal CCHP system control. The proposed method could smooth the errors between the forecasting and real-time data in a short time scale and reduce control cost as compared with FTL and FEL modes. Zhou et al. [157] investigated the day-ahead control strategy for integrated community energy system through MILP model. The uncertainty of renewable energy including wind and solar, as well as the uncertainty of price market, was taken into consideration. The uncertain parameters were predicted via Gaussian process method. Marino et al. [26] investigated CCHP system control strategy under uncertainty of electricity. The uncertain demand was assumed to follow a normal distribution. Two-stage optimization was implemented, in which the uncertainty occurred in the second stage. A hybrid sample average approximation algorithm with enhanced benders decomposition algorithm was used. Ji et al. [158] applied a fuzzy-risk-explicit interval parameter programming method to solve the system control problem under random energy price. The method can be expanded to tackle fuzzy and interval uncertainties in terms of various cost coefficients, forecasted demands, decision maker's risk attitude and other uncertainties in microgrid system management. Farmani [159] formulated deterministic and stochastic operation optimization problem. Monte Carlo method was used to produce a large number of scenarios to simulate uncertainties including weather conditions, forecast price, and then be clustered by K-mean method. Results show that the proposed smart controller could significantly reduce the operating cost by considering the correlation between historical data. However, there lack enough investigations on uncertainties influences of all kinds of demands, energy market, and energy conversion subsystems.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The reviewed papers show that the optimization techniques applied in design, planning and control stages have been updated rapidly due to fast expanding renewable energy, enriched energy conversion subsystems, added energy storage systems and diversified energy demand in CCHP systems. In CCHP system optimization, nonlinear system models make the optimization work much more difficulty to solve. Dynamic optimization is another feature of CCHP system optimization with storage system. Short, middle or long term dynamic optimization study have been distinguished based on the time range. GAMS, YALMIP, AMPL and LINGO are the most respectful platforms to construct the MILP, NLP or MINLP optimization model. At the same time, multi-objective optimization has earned more attention than single objective since energy efficiency and environment impact are of equal importance. Evolutionary algorithms like GA, PSO and DE are the most commonly used algorithms due to their robustness and easy-applicability. Weigh method and ε-constrain method are effective in dealing with simple system model.

The design optimization is applied based on the structure of CCHP system from top energy sources to the middle energy conversion subsystems. For energy source, renewable energy has been frequently adopted in the CCHP system optimization due to its superiority in environment and economic aspects. Solar energy is the intensively investigated renewable energy that has been adopted in CCHP system optimization. However, other renewable energies like geothermal, wind and biomass have their own development potential and need for more investigation. In addition, the intermittent feature of most renewable energy is a challenge for system optimization study with uncertainty, which should be considered at system control stage. Overall, CCHP system has become more reliable and more flexible in its energy source, which in turn raises the difficulties of accurate and efficient control. As for the optimization related to energy conversion subsystems, PM choice is intensively investigated as the core of CCHP system. ICE is still the most popular PM under most condition. However, there is a trend for scaling down the CCHP system. FC, MT, and SE are the candidate technologies for small-scale CCHP systems. Whereas insufficient investigation has been conducted for CCHP systems with small-scale PMs and their capital cost is the largest obstacle of development. Storage systems are introduced for stabilizing system performance and further improving energy efficiency and cost. However, dynamic operating conditions for storage systems and mal-distribution problem are seldom revealed in the system design optimization. Fresh water is added as an additional demand for CCHP system design optimization. However, there is no practical water demand data referred in the optimization work, which made the optimization work less convincing. Integration of every subsystem optimization to system configuration optimization was attempted. However, current research works only enumerated limited number of system configurations that are not sufficient for configuration optimization. Definitely, enriched CCHP systems would make subsystem modeling more complicated. Matrix decoupling concept may be able to alleviate the optimization problem. For a fixed system configuration, optimum control yields the best operation strategy in a target time range. Load following methods are the basic control strategies. They cannot guarantee a global optimum even though they are widely used for CCHP system control due to their easiness in implementation. Besides, the mismatch between prediction and actual need have to be considered in optimum control. Real-time data such as energy demand and ambient condition should be evaluated when studying control optimization. Uncertainty appears everywhere in a CCHP system. However, only uncertainties in energy demand or market price are considered. There is a need for a thorough study on uncertainties in CCHP systems including every energy demand, energy conversion subsystems and market price at the same time.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: CCHP system shows its potential in building sustainability in terms of high energy efficiency, low economic investment and low environment impact. An energy saving of 80% can be achieved compared with separated system. In order to further improving system efficiency, various optimization techniques have been intensively implemented to choose the best design and control strategy of CCHP system. This paper fills the gap of a comprehensive review on optimization study of CCHP systems. A total number of 232 papers that fall into the area of CCHP optimization have been reviewed. There is a sharp increase of investigation since 2015 due to expansion of optimization technologies and enhancement of computational power.

Basic knowledge of optimization and major algorithms used in CCHP system optimization are introduced first. Both continuous and discrete variables are involved in CCHP optimization for the operation characteristics of subsystems. Economic efficiency is the most investigated aspect in single objective optimization. Multi-objective optimization is increasingly earning more attention than single objective nowadays since energy efficiency and environment impact are of equal importance. Evolutionary algorithms are the most frequently used ones to approximate the optimal solution. Then the latest optimization research progress at design and operation planning stage are discussed. Detailed analysis within four regions of CCHP system and system configuration optimization are summarized in this stage. Renewable energies show their potential in CCHP system improvement in terms of energy efficiency and environmental benefits. Solar energy takes about 63% of the total research work among all the CCHP optimization study with renewable energy. And small scale prime movers that are below the capacity of 20 kW like fuel cell, Stirling engine and microturbine show their possibility of utilization in residential market while the costly investment prevents the development of practical implementation. Last, system control optimization considering real-time data and uncertainty are reviewed. Basic following load control method is easy to implement but cannot guarantee a best control strategy. MPC method is adopted to eliminate computational complexity and provides reliable supply under real time control case. However, MPC method is difficult in tuning up. For mitigating the uncertainty influence of CCHP from energy sources, subsystems to energy demands. Storage systems are introduced to improve stability and contribute to a dynamic programming problem compared with no storage system. In the area of multi-objective CCHP optimization, researchers always take different indexes to evaluate the 3E criteria. As the increase of diversified subsystems, there is a need to develop a comprehensive assessment method for different aspects of each criterion. A new equation that considers flexibility of primary energy source, uniformity of energy supply and convenience of optimization is proposed in this review paper to evaluate energy efficiency aspect. Even though solar energy is an appealing energy source, the lower energy density and intermittent production hinder the efficient control of renewable energy in CCHP system. Therefore, more emphasis should be placed on uncertainty issues for a solar-driven or -assisted CCHP system when conducting optimization work. To enlarge the CCHP system market via small scale PM, new system configurations or control strategies should be designed for fuel cell, microturbine or Stirling engine to overcome the costly investment. Storage system is a way to deal with system uncertainty, but they are always treated as lumped parameters, which cannot reflect the internal characteristics like misdistribution of thermal energy storage. Nonlinear subsystem performance, uncertainty issue together with dynamic feature of storage system further complicate the computation process in CCHP system optimum control. An approximation approaches might be a good route to figure the optimization problem out, which needs more investigation in the future. Computational efficiency will automatically be discount as the system complexity increase. There should be more discussion about the balance between accurate optimum solution and calculation time. This will be quit beneficial for long time range online control of CCHP system.
